comment_text: Thank you for taking the time to watch this video. I'd also like to thank the US Navy Public Affairs Officers who helped coordinate this. After clearing the video for OPSEC, they did not limit my creativity in anyway whatsoever. I decided to make a video about the Command Structure on the submarine so we had a better foundation moving forward in the Submarine Deep Dive. This video is just the beginning! I have some incredible things to show you as a part of the deep dive. Please consider subscribing for those. I'm most grateful to people who go the extra mile and support Smarter Every Day on Patreon. It's a super big deal because it brings stability to Smarter Every Day in ways that's hard to describe. In this case, I had to buy a plane ticket to the Arctic on relatively short notice. If you'd like to become a Patron, I'd greatly appreciate it. I worked for Electric Boat and we spent a few years transferring the US Navy Enlisted and Officers, Basic Submarine Qualifications Program, for the Trident Ballistic Missile Submarine,  from a paper based system with dozens of books and manuals, to a laser disk, digital computer based system.  We put workstations on board Ohio Class Subs and at ports like Kings Bay, GA and Bangor, Washington, so crews could do work on board and when on base to get through their quals to get their Silver or Gold Dolphins.  It was amazing to learn all about the systems that make up a Boomer!

My uncle was Air Force, enlisted, 22 years.  He always spoke of how it was the Master Chief's job to take care of the men.  Also spoke of how freshly minted officers, right out of school, would either shut up, listen and learn from the senior enlisted or they'd try to act as know-it-all bosses.  The latter usually didn't last long but the former would make excellent officers as they rose in ranks.

I loved that they had the Toledo Mudhens on the drink dispenser.  Way to represent!!  Might have to find a Toledo Walleye decal and see how to send it to them.  This series is so interesting. Thank you for the insight!

The correct answer is "more money"
It's literally the first thing they tell you when you sign up.
Submariners also get massive sign on bonuses, and most rates have massive re-enlistment bonuses as well.
My sign on bonus was $20k USD. If I re-enlisted, I would have gotten somewhere around $75k [I was a nuclear operator, and it's high demand]. I knew people who got more.
But yeah....the "someone has to do it" line is absolute BS. We do it for the money and that's it. The job is so horrible that the military HAS to incentivize it with higher pay, or else nobody would do it willingly.

Good representation of the life on a Fast Attack boat even though you were kept up forward. I served as a "Steely-Eyed Missile Man" aboard a Fleet Ballistic Missile (FBM) submarine back in the mid-70's. Our mission profile back then was significantly different from our brethren in the Attack boats - both ship types are very quiet and endeavor to stay hidden in our operating area but the FBM differs in that we were the larger strategic threat to our adversaries and we stayed on patrol for much longer duration. Also, the Fast Attack missions are more free-form and they have the flexibility (as the CO said) to execute them as the situation warrants. They also get to surface the boat from time to time when it is appropriate and to visit ports. FBM's don't surface unless they are told to or in the event of a potentially disastrous casualty situation. The FBM mission cycle when I served on them was 3 months on - 3 months off. But that aside, the particulars of crew structure, qualification requirements, comradery, and professionalism were exactly the same. FBM crew members get 2 patrols to become qualified - it is pretty rare for anyone to get their quals done in 1 patrol although I missed doing it by one signature since I was the Laundry Queen on my first patrol and therefore had plenty of opportunities to move about the boat and get signatures from watch-standers - plus there was the added factor of being the guy who was washing their skivvies - you want to take care of that guy right?
BTW: The Chief's quarters are called the Goat Locker and the Captain was obviously given an open invitation to be in their space - I seriously doubt that anyone else on the boat has that sort of unrestricted access unless it might be the XO. The only thing you didn't focus on was the food - it's probably the best in the Navy. I look forward to seeing more of these videos. Brings back memories.

Tried to figure out that T-shirt formula. It's not an equation - there's no equal sign. I recognized the first part. Looks suspiciously like E=mc2, so if I rearrange...that first part is m (mass). At this point I still didn't get it, even though I noticed the "established" below the formula and even though the video captions were on and screamed at me: "I'm a grad student at MIT in the MIT Woods Hole". That's 2 MIT's in one sentence. Hey, it's Sunday morning, give me a break.
The next part is an impossible square root. You can't take a square root of a negative number, it's undefined. Well...you could cheat and replace it with an imaginary number, most often denoted with "i" and ... this is where i realized I the last part of the 'formula' had to be 'T'!

So, that last part...R for radius? P for momentum? V for velocity? T for torque formula? Nope.
So I learned about the ideal gas law, which is quite intuitive: the pressure P at a valve of a gas cylinder gets higher as the temperature (T) and amount of gas (n) increase, but it gets lower if the volume (V) becomes larger. Add a constant to make the units balance out and you get: P = (nT/V) R, or as written on the T-shirt: PV/nR = T.
Gettin' smarter every day. Thanks.

Although capable these subs are pretty noisy by today's standards and new Russian and Chinese submarines are definitely stealthier and more advanced than these boats. That's why Navy should invest more into the silent service and speed up the building rate of the new Block V Virginia class submarines. Virginia class is by far the most advanced SSN in the world, especially future boats that will receive the VPM, or Virginia payload module, which will add space for 12 additional Tomahawks since we will loose a large amount of capacity when 4 SSGNs start retiring later in the decade..

A few decades ago various services from various countries would send a set of requirements to a certain watch company that said what kind of watch the military wants them to make for them. That was especially important for pilots of yesteryear who received pilot's watches that were actually used as instruments during flight. Also navies around the world wanted water resistant watches for their divers and that resulted in a popular diving watch category.
Today there are no military issued watches which is a shame, at least for the guys who used to receive their IWCs, Hamiltons, Lacos and watches from other various Swiss companies, for free. Putting that aside, I can observe that the large number of current soldiers, airman and sailors, that buy and pay for their own watches, wear the good old Casio G shock.. 50 years ago you could see a Blancpain Fifty fatoms strapped to an arm of a French master diver. Today nobody would wear a 20 000$ Fifty fatoms while on a mission. This is where a dirt cheap, functional and almost bulletproof G shock comes into play..
In that tone the captain of this nuclear submarine wears one, although I have no doubt he could afford and wear the Rolex Submariner.

Analyzing the way that they dive a submarine (the procedure, specifically) has been a really interesting thing for me. From my research, it depends on the class of the submarine, but it mostly follows this procedure. Submariners please correct me. Also, I am going to explain some somewhat basic naval stuff, please correct me if I'm wrong.:

It starts with the officer of the deck informing everyone in the control room (including the captain) of the current status of the ship, water depth (including verifying it with a map), and the depth they intend to dive to. Anywhere they say "stationary dive", it would normally just be "dive" but because they are surrounded by ice, they have to go under the ice before they can move. In this case, that was:
" The ship is rigged for dive, with the exception of arctic full blow (ship status) and a sounding of 1490 fathoms beneath the ship (water depth, "Sounding" is how they measure depth), checks with chart at water depth (verifying the sounding depth). I intend to stationary dive the ship to 180 feet. (their intents)."

The commanding officer of the sub responds "very well officer of the deck, submerge the ship", saying that the information they have given was enough and giving the officer of the deck permission to carry out the plan he just announced.

The Officer of the Deck reads back that order "submerge the ship, aye sir", and issues an order to the crew:
"Dive. Stationary dive the ship to 180 feet".


The Diving Officer of the Watch (I think) repeats back that order "stationary dive the ship to 180 feet, dive aye." and gives an order to the Chief of the Watch "Chief of the watch, on the 1MC (the 1MC is the primary, ship-wide PA system) Stationary Dive, Stationary Dive" Destin cut out the rest of this order which would be something along the lines of "sound 2 blasts of dive alarm, Stationary Dive, Stationary Dive."

Then, the Chief of the watch would (I think) repeat back that order, then announce on the 1MC "Stationary Dive, Stationary Dive", sound the dive alarm/claxon twice, then repeat "Stationary Dive, Stationary Dive". The dive alarm is sounded 2x for diving and 3x for surfacing, and the same goes for the announcement (if they were surfacing it they would say "surface, surface, surface")

At this point, the pilots set their control surfaces, and someone (depending on the class of the sub) presses buttons/flips switches to open the vents on the ballast tanks to flood them with seawater, and they announce "all vents open", and someone (once again, depends on the class) verify that the vents are open on the periscope since that could be catastrophic if only one tank vents, because the sub could go to a bad angle, lose control, etc. As they do this, they announce "venting forward/aft" depending on which vent they are looking at.

According to unclassified navy manuals, if there is any confusion as to who could be responding to an order when they repeat it back, they append "position, aye", so if it was an order for the pilot, they would append "pilot, aye".

This procedure they run through is just mesmerizing to me as a teen. If I got anything wrong, PLEASE correct me. I am always eager to learn.
Now I know why submariners are such an elite society ... the best of the best!

Whoa... I think I missed this part last time I watched this vid... 13:20 talks about underwater navigation that is as accurate as GPS. On the sub, aside from sonar, radar, and GPS we use gyros to track where we've been. When you're under the water however, both the current and conflicting drift will throw you off course while plotting your charts. If you don't come up for weeks or months, you could be hundreds of nautical miles off course...

My folks moved into a retirement home in Colorado in 2016 and I happened to be in town the day one of the "inmates" (my Dad's term) gave a presentation on the launching of the USS Colorado. He was a multi-tour veteran of Navy submarine life and had been invited to attend a couple of weeks earlier. At the end of the christening, they allowed a few distinguished guests (including him) to board and tour the sub before it launched. At the top of the sub, a difficult climb for him in his late 80's (early 90's?) stood one final security check. The guy asked him if he was sure he could navigate the ladder down. He said, "I looked at him and said, "(addressing him by rank), if I botch this thing and end up dead on the tile there at the bottom, at this point, I can't think of a better way to go." He said the guy stood back as straight as an arrow, saluted him, and announced, "Permission granted, sir." It was freakin' awesome!! ;)

When I was a CCF Royal Navy Cadet 32 years ago, I got to spend a week at HMS Dolphin, working on HMS Sovereign - RN Nuclear Attack Sub.  Really surprised at the aesthetic differences and similarities. The biggest difference is the relationship between officers and crew.  The RN was a lot more formal... don't know if that's still true.  Also I got to see the reactor up close... like 2 meters from it.  British boats, from what I remember, seemed tidier.  While being smaller... and yet the US boat looks more cramped.  That may also be a trick of the memory.   Brought back some cool memories.

I am so grateful to be alive today. My girlfriend saved my life last night. This is a selfie I took in the emergency room after having a severe allergic reaction to almonds. I went into anaphylaxis, meaning my face, my lips, my eyes, my tongue, and my throat all started swelling up rapidly, making it almost impossible for me to breathe. I also had a rash all over my entire body, and I was extremely red. Staying alive had never felt more difficult. At one point, my nasal passage was completely blocked, and it was getting more and more difficult to breathe. They shot me up with Benadryl, steroids, they gave me a breathing tube, and even other stuff that I can’t even remember, and it caused all of the swelling and the rash to go away. Because this was a severe allergic reaction, I need to continue taking steroids and Benadryl for the next week, because it is possible that the allergic reactions could come back at any point over the next week. The steroids and Benadryl make me feel like a zombie, and I really want to take care of my health, so this will be my main focus over the next week. I want to thank my amazing girlfriend, who made the decision to take me to the emergency room the second I started feeling itchy. I was hesitant about going, because I didn’t even want to believe this was actually happening. If it weren’t for my girlfriend driving me to the emergency room only minutes after eating the almonds, there is a good chance that I wouldn’t have made it according to the doctor. This has been without a doubt the hardest few days of my life, but I also look at them as the most important few days of my life. These moments have reminded me about what’s really important in life, and it has made me so grateful to even be here on this earth. I will be prioritizing my health over the next week, and I’ll post updates about how I feel. Thank you all for being patient during these difficult times. This week has been NUTS (too soon for jokes? 😅)

There's a lot of things that have to happen to professionally integrate women in and things you wouldn't normally think of complicate the process. For example, everything is close quarters and require passage through birthing areas, sometimes very very often. Well, you have men showering, changing, etc. When I was in, they had to stop, announce "female on deck", and wait for anyone naked to get covered, THEN pass through (although in practice they just announced and walked through and nobody cared). But you can imagine how much time this would waste. This is just one example, but don't be surprised that it takes this long, these ships are designed to last a LONG TIME, but new ones since late 1990's started building in these changes.

I also feel that psychological evaluations/tests need to be done to see how a crew reacts with a single female on board. Yes all USN submariners are professional and highly trained they are still human.

Just my 2 cents.

Perhaps I missed it, but did anyone mention that no one on a submarine is rested? That is my most vivid memory of my time on the Henry M Jackson. No sleep. You operate on an 18 hour "day". Stand watch for 6 hours. Do PMs (Preventative Maintenance) on your equipment for 4. Work on equals for 2-4 hours (depending on if you are "dink" or deliquent)  Then try eat, shower and hit the rack for maybe 2 hours sleep... That is always interrupted by a drill or 2... I tell people that the Navy arm of our nuclear triad, is a Trident sub cruising around with 160 guys who would probably nuke Tulsa for 8 solid hours of sleep

LTJG Mace is the Supply Officer, he runs the crews mess, ships retail store, orders all spare parts, and in the old days he was the paymaster...now pay is by electronic direct deposit.  All Supply Officer's are nicknamed "chop" since the left collar insignia for a supply officer looks like a "pork chop" but it's really an oak leaf with two acorns.  The left collar insignia for all of the other officers is a star designating them as "line" officers.  The Commanding Officer's right collar insignia is a silver oak leaf.  To be assigned as the only Supply Officer on a ship or submarine is called "independant duty"; you have to be the top of your Supply Corps graduating class to be selected for independant duty.

USS Daniel Boone SSBN 629-Blue Crew.  I was a Nuclear Propulsion Plant Operator for 4 years on the Boone ending in 1982.  I wish they could show the engineering spaces where I worked.  I guess nobody will ever know what it was like back aft except the few of us who worked there.  Everyone working in the engineering spaces had to undergo training at Nuclear Power School and Nuclear Prototype School as well as the training they received for their particular rating (in my case Machinist Mate School).  Could be as much as 2 years of training before you even get to the ship.  Then you had to train on the systems for your specialty as well as the systems of the whole ship to earn your coveted "Dolphins".  MM-1 TJ Chriss.

I kind of want to point out that there's a difference between the title of captain and the actual rank. The skipper (Captain, or whoever is in charge of the ship) is always called Captain, regardless of their actual rank. In the Navy captains are the equivalent to the Air Force, Army, and Marine officer rank of Colonel. Aircraft Carriers are always captained by a captain, but submarines are often (As in the case of this ship in the video) captained by Lieutenant Commanders.

The command structure in the military has levels where each level has an officer and an enlisted person in charge. The enlisted people have working knowledge of what they are in charge of, the officers have "book" knowledge of what they are in charge in. If we were to copy this structure in the civilian word, you would have employees who are promoted up from the lowest positions in the organization performing the role of the enlisted guy in charge at each level, and you would have guys with university degrees or higher performing the role of the officer in charge at each level. Think of it as a way of recognizing the fact that practical knowledge and formal "book" knowledge are two separate things.

It took me a minute to appreciate the writing on the shirt at 11:48. For those who haven't figured it out here it is. E/c^2 is mass, or M. Square root of -1 is i, and PV/nR is temperature, T, so it spells out MIT.

This is great, one thing i have always wondered regarding the whole, subs under ice thing is how they decide which ice to punch through, can they punch through any ice, is the boat hardened specifically to punch through the ice, does it have a spike on the conning tower to do so, how does it feel inside the sub when it punches through the ice, is it like a crazy earthquake in there. Hope some of these questions can be answered in this series.

Btw, in case peopled missed it. The formula on Lt. Bradley Howard's t-shirt 'translates' to MIT

M=E/c2 *(that's Einstein's famous formula)
sqrt(-1) being normally identified by 'i' (imaginary number), so that's a concept from number theory
and the T comes out of the last part which is from thermodynamics, if you re-arrange the last part of the formula on her t-shirt
So it's not a formula per-se, but more a riddle :)

First, I want to say that I was very impressed with the access that the Navy gave you, that you were permitted to film with the only restriction being a review for operational security, and with how respectful you were to the sailors you met and interviewed.  It may have been a bit disconcerting for you, but you handled it well.  As a former fast attack sailor (MM1/SS) qualified on a 688, this brought back a ton of memories (most of them good).  Some things that your video didn't mention, though it was sort of hinted at, sailors have to volunteer for submarine duty.  There is not a lot of down time for the new guy, between learning their job and qualification (both in their rate (job assignment), as well as submarine quals for their dolphins.  Those "beds" that you didn't get to see in birthing are typically shared, three sailors assigned to two racks (hot racking, look it up) because they work a rotating shift every day of the week at sea.  To answer one of the questions I saw on the comments, yes, some of the sailors are married, officers and enlisted, and yes, it can be tough, though as I understand it, things have gotten better than when I was in as far as communicating back home.  As a Navy vet, sailors are special to me, and submariners even more so.  Thanks again for presenting this, because it may be the only insight some folks ever have into life onboard a fast attack sub.

Something that strikes me in this video, and maybe this is a lame observation that should be obvious, but I was intrigued by how inaccurate Hollywood's perception of the military is. Movies always portray the military as unintelligent and the antagonists of scientists and anthropologists. But in reality, people in the military typically receive more education and training that people who work in other fields. It also makes sense that people in the military would respect scientists and engineers because those are the people who create devices that keep them safe and plan missions in a way that protects all the people involved. I know that it's a well-known fact that the media almost never portrays things accurately, but seeing this video made me realize how much of a shame it is that Hollywood creates this negative stereotype of people in the military and devalues what they do. Many of the people in the military are engineers, researchers, and experts in their field. Moreover, they are dedicated to their work and extremely hard working. More people should know this.

Excellent video.  Superb discussions with both officers and crew.  My late father was a submarine medical officer in the early days of our nuke "boats" as they used to be lovingly called.  The specific boat my dad was a plank owner of was USS SWORDFISH (SSN-579).  I, too, served in the Navy.  That said, while in the service I never stepped foot of a ship other than USS RECRUIT (at NTC, San Diego).  I got interested in Pacific War history in the mid-1950's while my family was living on Oahu.  I'm still extremely interest in our Navy's role in World War II.  Some folks may be drawn to subs because of HazPay, but I suspect the vast majority of them go into subs because it is as "tight" a community as one will ever find either in the service or in civilian life.  I'm 72.  I went into the Navy on 24 August 1970, and was honorably discharged out on 10 November 1971.  I dearly love the personnel of the United States Navy.  I'll be proud of all those who serve until the day I die.  Thank you for this truly fantastic video.  Education at its best.  Go Navy!

When push came to shove, the only thing the officers cared for was getting their flight hours. The working environment was just awful too, surrounded by extreme nose, toxic chemicals and fumes. After 9 years I had enough and left. A character building experience for sure but I would not recommend anyone become an aircraft mechanic in the Navy.

If you know how a nuclear reactor works, you can see how the reactor on a submarine works. The enriched Uranium rods are placed in a containment vessel inside the reactor. Said vessel is inside a tank of pressurized water. The Uranium heats up the boilers, and the steam generated by the boilers drives a turbine, which in turn powers a generator that charges the batteries. This was a basic overview. Naval reactor technology is not some super special secret classified thing, contrary to popular belief.

I agree with XO: Submarines have best people in the Navy, smartest people in the Navy. Best & smartest people in the world. When you leave the Navy you will NEVER work with group of people you trust like you trust fellow crew on a submarine. Think ---- There are no lifeboats on a submarine. "We" save the boat and we all go home. Or, "we'" don't save the boat and nobody goes home. Much much different relationship with fellow crew than any other branch of service. On a submarine it is always all about the boat. Never about you. Never about me. Always about the boat.

fyi... I was Cold War Navy 6 years (1968-74), ballistic missile nuclear submarine, Patrick Henry SSBN-599. I was enlisted ELT (reactor chemistry, radiation monitoring, etc). And, engine room supervisor (ERS). There are 1000 jobs on a submarine. And only 130 crew (give or take). Every crew member has 3 or 4 or 5 jobs.

fyi2.. My job required that I do many calculations (math). I used a slider rule. No computers in my day. I did not see my first 4-function calculator until my last patrol. And there was 1 on the whole boat. Today's submarines are way, way more advanced than mine. My boat was decommissioned and scrapped 1984. It is now a steel bridge somewhere.

Destin, my apologies if someone has already mentioned the name of the plant from the end of your video as I did not read through all of them. Its known as butterfly weed. I run a small backyard nursery in TN and its a plant I will often times give away for free solely because of its benefits in bringing in pollinators. You're right, butterflies do love it, hence its name. But many, many other insects are drawn to it as well. I see more bees in mine than butterflies, at times 20+ on a single plant. They are wonderful plants and can really increase the biodiversity of an area. They are very hardy and can even withstand huge aphid numbers, which in turn lures in ladybugs, the larvae of which are known as aphid lions. Again its a wonderful plant with many benefits and I thank you for bringing attention to it! Best wishes!
- Matt from Midnight Farms

So for the record… if you had to clear your footage prior to its publication, then you were definitely not “free to say whatever [you] want!” Rather, you voluntarily fitted yourself into the US Navy’s requirements, and your resulting footage presented them no need to censor it. This may seem like a minor distinction, but these things matter: if you had to clear your footage first, then you were not free to present whatever you wanted.

Your self-contradicting statement is a little like saying “I was free to tell this story however I wanted! I mean, the company’s lawyer combed over the piece first, and had to approve it before I could publish it — but I so tightly conformed to what they wanted in the first place, that they let my initial cut through unchanged… ergo, I got to say whatever I wanted!” It attempts to falsely claim “clearing” isn’t control until edits are demanded.

But the subject of a report having final say over that report still amounts to speech control, even if you voluntarily meet the subject’s conditions. And while there are levels to the severity with which speech is controlled, it‘s false to pretend the US Armed Forces don’t practice a subtle kind of state-backed censorship. It’s not as bad as North Korea or Putin’s Russia, but its important to acknowledge and remain vigilant over.

12:28 E=MC^2 rearranged to find the M, you get E/C^2. In other words, the first letter is “M”. Square root of -1 is an imaginary number/complex number that can be written as a real number multiplied by the imaginary unit “i”, which is defined by its property i^2 = −1. In other words, the second letter is “I”, PV = nRT is the equation of state of a hypothetical ideal gas in thermodynamics, based on the “ideal gas law”. Rearranged, you get: T = PV / nR. Therefore, the third letter is “T”. MIT...

Being a submariner is one of the most difficult and demanding jobs. It really does take a specific type of person. Every submariner goes through things that they can't really talk about. There is little to no margin of error in what they do. Even cooking on a sub requires an extremely diverse skillset (not talking about just culinary skills) and attention to the smallest detail, and that's on top of cooking good food for all those people for months at a time. The level of trust they have in each other is something that usually takes a lifetime to build. They are the smartest and most dedicated people in the Navy. They are proud and dedicated but having an ego problem or immaturity excludes someone from sub service. That's why you'll never really see them publicly bragging the same way the Air Force does... it's a totally different ballgame.

I work in hydrography so it was interesting to see the MIT scientists onboard the sub. The device at 13:15 that the camera is strapped to is known as an SVP or sound velocity profiler. It makes a lot of sense that submarines in the arctic would need to use one, even though I had never really thought about it. Basically the SVP checks what the local speed of sound is. Which is really important because you have an interaction between frozen fresh water and liquid salt water. Both the salinity and temperature of the water impacts the speed of sounds in a not-insignificant manner so if you use the wrong salinity, the sonar on a sub will return a surface that may be metres off its actual position because it was doing all of the positional measurements using an incorrect speed of sound.

A few comments from a former submarine officer. The captain’s comments about under ice operations can not be emphasized enough. You have an inherently dangerous activity of operating a ship underwater and then you put it under ice. Under ice is not were you want to be. I was surprised to hear the captain spends significant time in the chiefs quarters. That is highly unusual. Training is a constant. You are either being trained or training someone else. Think about the workplace you work at and imagine if every person who worked there changed jobs about every 3-4 years and someone new came in. I don’t know about the statement that everyone loves their job, but I will say my experience was that overall they were a great group of guys (women weren’t on subs when I was in) and I was always amazed how well we generally got along. It’s hard work and a lot of hours. We hear about the basketball players that are “in the bubble” and how “tough” this is for them. The personnel serving on board our boats as you read this are really the ones in the bubble - and we don’t pay them millions of dollars to do it.

Great job on this video, takes me back.  While I served on USS Miami (SSN755) I never participated directly in ICEX.   We did have operations in that general area, well north of the Arctic Circle, but I can't comment on that too much.....   As a sonarman (STS2-SS  Sonar Tech Submarines 2nd class), we did do some under ice work with HF active sonar, but we did not breech the ice.  USS Toledo (SSN769) is almost identical to USS Miami (SSN755).  Both are Los Angeles-I (improved) class.  It has 12 vertical launch tubes on the bow, and retractable bow planes.   Inside looks identical to the Miami, except for the decorations on the bulkheads.   The formal coms in control as they prepare to dive the boat almost sound like another language, but I've spent thousands of hours communicating in such a way that it still feels natural.  Sometimes at home I'll repeat back commands that my wife gives me.

Thank you for posting this video! Very interesting! I wasn't able to go into the Armed Forces due to having Hemophilia. I wish I could have served --there is a cavernous void within me from not being able to serve my country. I've also wanted to go up with one of our Ace Pilots for a ride in a jet, but, I don't know if I'd be able to get into the cockpit --cant bend my legs too well from the hundreds of injuries on each knee through the years. I also wish I could go into a sub but there's no way I can climb down a ladder. I'd love to go on a Carrier, a battleship, a helicopter and have a professional show me, teach me and let me fire a few guns on a range --never fired any in my life. And lastly, I'd LOVE to visit the White House & meet The President, visit the Capitol, Library of Congress, etc. Being on a fixed income I can't afford any of that if I was healthy enough to go, which is admittingly more rare. Thank you all who serve! Thank you to all who have served! I'm one individual who knows the painful (physical and mentally and emotionally) sacrifices you have had to make, both willingly and un. I thank you as an American citizen.

Such a shame that they still think they need to hide the reactor compartment and engine room from public view.  The only item that was an actual secret was the number of control rods and the steam pressure and reactor coolant temperature.  This has long ago become public knowledge and Tom Clancy pretty much figured it out on his own and published the temperature parameters in "The Hunt for Red October" back in the early 80's.  He was remarkably close for both Russian and American systems.  I have no clue why they would consider the number and arrangement of control rods a secret.  Basic physics determines an optimal layout.  I was a reactor operator for an Ohio class sub and a Nimitz class aircraft carrier.  Our "enemies" have long ago placed moles in our Navy and know the complete details of our systems, just as we know complete details of theirs.  It's pretty much a joke now.  Was dumbfounded at the fact that sailors on CVN-71 were live streaming on social media when their Captain was departing the ship in the Covid fiasco.  So much for operational security.

Call of Dustin action game plot: 2045 a man named Dustin, travels to the Arctic to interview a nuclear submarine crew for educational purposes and they take on a journey for a few days in the submarine. He learns tons of information about the job and has plenty of chats that give him an insight into what their life is like underwater and also how to combat and survive in harsh conditions. Second night at 2:45am: Dustin wakes up to the sound of a loud emergency alarm. Red light beacons rotate giving a clear image of an emergency. He can hear the crew speaking and giving commands loudly through the door. The first thing he does is dress up, put on protective gear, and turn on his camera to record. He comes out of his room and everybody is rushing to their computer seats and positions. He stays still for a moment not knowing what's really going on. Dustin, ready to take action and help in any way he can, approaches the crew to ask what is the emergency but they seem to not want to tell him because he could enter in panic giving the seriousness of the situation. After a few failed attempts to make the crew tell him about the situation, the Commanding Officer orders Dustin to go to (the safest place in the submarine). Dustin sees in the CO eyes that something is out of the ordinary so he wants to keep him safe, but at that moment... nobody was safe no more. As Dustin is turning back, an explosion occurs inside the sub and he is knocked unconscious. Everyone is disoriented at this point. After a few minutes, a crew member wakes Dustin up and yells "Follow me!". Water is flooding the inside. They rush to an emergency exit pod and make it just in time. They were the last ones to exit but they don't know that and they hope everyone is ok. They can see from inside the pod's glass walls that the submarine is sinking and breaking apart as they get away from it. "It was an enemy attack," the crew member said. and it is at this moment that Dustin realizes that his life would never be the same.

This is a survival game where Dustin must explore the Arctic for resources to survive, find the rest of the crew, and find out who was the attacker and why they did it (plot twist included). The crew member he scaped with will teach and help him survive and combat enemies and will become one the allies from the many he can choose from to help him as he progresses in the story. At the end of the game, Dustin has learned many skills and has accomplished many tasks and formed an alliance of military, civilian, and animal companions, built structures, and created a society.

Thank you Destin for one of the most well rounded looks into the world that I had the pleasure to serve in for 20 yrs. I was on the 640 class, aka "41 for freedom" and the Ohio class (both SSBN and SSGN). I greatly appreciate the way you went about explaining the command structure, as well as the unique interpersonal dynamics. A few things about life on subs: 1.) It's called the "Silent Service" for a reason. Noises on submarines is the fastest way to reveal your position. "Sound-shorts", e.g., a dropped wrench in the bilge area, can be detected for miles. 2.) The quality of the food is directly proportional to the attitude and morale of the crew. 3.) Flashlights in berthing areas = imminent pain and suffering. 4.) LEARN EVERYTHING...it could save not only your life, but everyone's.

May I suggest that these amazing people are only half of the equation. You may want to do a follow up segment...the families that are left back home for months at a time. It may not be the intellectual deep dive that you usually take on, but I promise you that you will discover the real power behind our submariners. The strength and tenacity of the spouses, and the emotional trials and tribulations that the family go through are worthy of some recognition.
I can't wait to see the rest of this series.

Hey Destin. Your dosimetry goes by the name TLD, short for thermoluminescent dosimeter. The sailors wear them on their belts, I imagine you wore your TLD on your chest. They were right in that you receive more radiation on a flight then on a nuclear powered ship. The US navy has done a lot in lowering radiation exposure sailors receive while onboard a nuclear powered vessel. I would be interested to know, if the navy allows it, what radiation exposure you received while on board. Meaning, what did your TLD measure as your exposure. I bet it read 0.0. This is important because I don't believe the general public understands radiation exposure. I've heard people joke and say something like, "you'll turn green from that radiation," which is funny, but that might be the extent of the person's knowledge of radiation exposure. Something to think about. Enjoyed the video, I look forward to your future videos in this series.

I have been waiting for something like this to get some YouTube Love. I am a retired Navy Submariner (21 years on Los Angeles Class Fast Boats, 1981-2002). As someone with 0 experience or knowledge about this stuff, you would either expect a overly serious enviroment or almost the opposite, a very lax enviroment where people operate on mainly experience etc. But this enviroment seems like such a perfect inbetween, they have a (mental) space for the crew that allows them to relax, be friends and connect, but this space isn't cut off from the "serious mode" (lack of better term). Instead they flow perfectly with eachother, it's like a healthy mix of co-worker and friendship and it sounds like it allows them to really push eachother in healthy, as well as very productive ways. It almost looks like a good relationship between two partners where both are very humble and gives their partner 90% effort, when both partners do the same, a nice equalibrium is created. It's like that but except with 150+ people lmao.

But it's really cool to see, I've always thought these kind of enviroments are perfect for learning (*cough* schools) in contrast to trying to force people into a rigid mold. It seems more like the commanding officers and captain are able to make small adjustments over periods of time to make sure the crew can perform and evolve at the best level possible.

On the one hand, I really appreciate first-hand perspectives. This is a thoughtful and interesting examination of operations aboard a modern American submarine. On the other hand, being directly there with the people, can hamper the reporter's ability to remain objective.

I think it was interesting to see the racial disparity among the crew. In the course of the video, only three people were present that were apparently people of color, between the XO, the Chief Petty Office, and a crewman. From the sweeping videos, they seem to be a tiny minority among the enormously white crew, when Hispanic and Black peoples compose about 31% of the national population. I would be interested, when free of Navy censorship and immediate obligations to fellow crew members, to hear their perspectives on their work and the environment in which they worked.

This is outstanding. It's easy to see the high quality of the submariners and how much they enjoy being there. It's really nice to take a peek inside the way you see it. You bring out the "people part" of the story very well. I just saw the top of a Fairbanks-Morse diesel engine! I didn't know they still used those in subs. Go down to Mobile and check out the USS Drum. You can see the top crankshaft cover of the Fairbanks Morse diesel engine in that gorgeous WWII sub. The engine has an upper and lower crankshaft with dual opposing pistons in each cylinder. They are fascinating design. We used to use them for gas compression drivers in the oil and gas business. Ours were turbocharged, super charged, or turbo-supercharged. They are extremely loud. Big horsepower (and torque) make big noise. I'm already subbed but I'm looking forward to this series...

That flower is called "Butterfly Weed" or Asclepias tuberosa. There are a few different varieties but are required for Monarch's. Please don't handle them or let your kids handle them as they can cause blistering much like poison ivy and are toxic to animals and humans. They are a pretty flower and butterflies do love them. We have a bunch planted around our house, outside or finger reach of little hands, so that they Monarchs and other butterflies can enjoy them. Also check out "Gregg's Blue Mist" or "Butterfly Bush" as they are non-toxic and butterflies love them.

It's great that you don't brush-hog them as butterflies (Monarchs) will lay their eggs in them. You can find out more from your local Ag department or check out the Monarch migratory path, or just search for "Butterfly Weed".

Loved the job, work environment sucks. Life is easier underway because of the structured routine.

However, the stress takes a huge toll on you. In the end, you'll come out mentally stronger and capable. If you're seriously considering this path, let me know. I won't sugar coat anything but after you get your fish (dolphins) you gain a huge respect from the crew. Life will suck before then?, as you're seen as a Non-essential Useless Body. 1 of the boats I was on named mandatory group learning for unqualified personnel "Nub of the Sub" my other boats called it "School of the Boat" . Nowadays everything is PC friendly, so you may not see hazing as bad as it used to be.

Great time over all, though. A really proud and dignified group of people.

I just want to drop a quick note to thank you beyond words for your video content. My 13 year old son and i absolutely love science. My son is a low level special needs learner,and your videos have inspired a very bright spark in my sons ability to learn anything science. You have a way of making even the most complex science,seem tangible. Your visual skills and expert moderation have not only helped my son become more interested in science, but now he is asking more and more questions, he is finding answers on his own,he has an insane fascination with the atom and how all of it works, especially nuclear power. When he and i were exploring how a nuclear bomb works,he started to make more sense of fission and fusion, especially with multi-staged warheads. Then he asked about the possibility of nuclear fusion power,so we explored that idea. All in all i have to say that starting your videos at least over a year or two ago has ignited an enormous spark in my boy. His main learning issue is with reading and comprehension. The docs and counselors have no reasoning behind what they call a neuro-disconnect. He is not on any realm as far as autism or dyslexia he just has some issues with reading and understanding what he has read.  But with your videos,he has began to read more often especially if it is an interesting subject for him. So to make a long story short,i just want to thank you from the bottom of my heart for all of the hard work and effort you put into all of your videos. Your use of visual keys in conjunction with the available information to help the "layman" to understand complex science is by far soo phenomenal. My son has gone from dreading reading,to he cannot wait for the next book to arrive or he cannot wait sometimes to finish reading something that interests him. We cannot wait to see the whole line of videos about the nuclear submarine. So in closing,thank you for all of your epic footage in everything, and know that we are becoming Smarter every day.

You should definitely try to get onto an Aircraft Carrier during a Tiger Cruise. They occur whenever a carrier is on it's last port before the mainland. My dad went on one when my brother was on the Carl Vinson in 2015. He flew to Hawaii and spent about 5 days on the ship. THe reason I bring this up is listening to your discussion with the COB on the sub reminded me of my dad's experience with the Chiefs on the Vinson. There is truth to the saying "Chiefs run the ship". He got to dine with the Chiefs and the Officers and said the Chiefs have better food. That's due to one simply reason...A chief is the one directing where pallets of food go once they are onboard. If they see some Prime ribs, they point to the Chiefs chow hall. I think you doing a video on a Tiger Cruise would be exceptional.

i am not convinced. i don't think any more than one or two people here is intentionally lying. i just find no evidence that anybody on board is splitting atoms to make that s~car go. Traditionally, subs are powered by simple electrolysis that any middle school child can replicate for a science fair project. Turns out, you end up with twice as much hydrogen as oxygen, hence H2O.

They use sea water with an anode, cathode and a little "juice" from a battery to separate the hydrogen and the oxygen from the salt water. This gives them all the oxygen needed to stay underwater for extended periods of time. The hydrogen fuels the ship, the ovens and "nuclear" bombs. i'd be curious where they claim to store enough oxygen to circulate to allow the ship to stay underwater for months at a time if it's not made as they go. Did they show you the section of the sub where all the oxygen is stored? Can you tell me even one place on earth that has ever experienced a nuclear incident that is not teaming with life today. Hey Destin, I would like to give you a little bit of feedback:
In my personal opinion, anything connected to war and armies is negative. I noticed that you upload videos that - from my perspective - support the army and their actions. Now, I am not saying that all people in the army/navy are bad and should not be thanked or respected. My problem is that a lot of people watch your videos and probably orientate themselves off of them. In my opinion, there is a risk, that (especially young) people watching your videos might be subliminally manipulated (in no way am I trying to suggest that you are doing that intentionally). This is why I prefer topics like these being discussed openly and critically in a clear context.

Please note that this will not stop me from watching your videos, as I enjoy both the content and your character and nature. :-) Just wanted to give you a little heads-up.

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Asclepias curassavica



Secure (NatureServe)[1]
Scientific classificationedit
Kingdom: Plantae
Clade: Tracheophytes
Clade: Angiosperms
Clade: Eudicots
Clade: Asterids
Order: Gentianales
Family: Apocynaceae
Genus: Asclepias

Binomial name
Asclepias curassavica
L.
Synonyms[2]
Asclepias nivea var. curassavica (L.) Kuntze

Asclepias curassavica, commonly known as tropical milkweed,[3] is a flowering plant species of the milkweed genus, Asclepias.[4] It is native to the American tropics[5] and has a pantropical distribution as an introduced species. Other common names include bloodflower or blood flower,[3] cotton bush,[6] hierba de la cucaracha,[3] Mexican butterfly weed, redhead,[6] scarlet milkweed,[3] and wild ipecacuanha.[3]

It is grown as an ornamental garden plant and as a food source for some butterflies, however it may be harmful to the migration patterns of monarch butterflies when used in gardens outside of its native tropical range.[7] Though public concern for the rapidly declining monarch population increased the demand and commercial availability of milkweed among nurseries in the USA, the results have been mixed. While tropical milkweed may effectively sustain monarch larvae, the perennial growth of the plant takes ill effect on the monarchs' migratory patterns and may have other physiological effects.[8] Use of the tropical milkweed in gardens has disrupted monarch migrations notably in California, Texas, Florida, and South Carolina.[9] Unlike the milkweed species native to these locations, the tropical milkweed does not go dormant in the winter causing non-migratory groups of butterflies to form. Planting Asclepias curassavica in nonnative regions therefore remains controversial and criticized. Alternatively, native milkweed species are suggested for butterfly gardens.[10]

It also attracts members of the Danainae subfamily, such as the queen.


Contents
1 Description
2 Cultivation
3 Distribution
4 Chemistry
5 Gallery
6 References
7 External links
Description
Typical plants are evergreen perennial subshrubs that grow up to 1 m (3.3 ft) tall and have pale gray stems. The leaves are arranged oppositely on the stems and are lanceolate or oblong-lanceolate shaped ending in acuminate or acute tips. Like other members of the genus, the sap is milky. The flowers are in cymes with 10-20 flowers each. They have purple or red corollas and corona lobes that are yellow or orange. Flowering occurs nearly year-round.[5] The 5–10 cm (2.0–3.9 in) long, fusiform shaped fruits are called follicles. The follicles contain tan to brown seeds that are ovate in shape and 6–7 mm (0.24–0.28 in) long. The flat seeds have silky hairs that allow the seeds to float on air currents when the pod-like follicles dehisce (split open).[11]

Cultivation
There are a number of different cultivars with improved flower colors and shorter habit; some have bright red, yellow or orange colored flowers. Asclepias curassavica is sometimes used in butterfly gardens (see above for concerns for monarchs) or as a cut flower. However, when the stems or leaves are broken, a poisonous milky sap exudes which can cause eye injury.[12]

Distribution
Asclepias curassavica is described by NatureServe as a "widespread species, ranging from southern North America through Central America and into South America."[1]

It is an introduced species in the US states of California, Florida, Hawaii, Louisiana, Tennessee, and Texas, as well as the US unincorporated territories of Puerto Rico and the United States Virgin Islands.[13]

It has been introduced and naturalized in the Chinese provinces of Anhui, Fujian, Guangdong, Guangxi, Guizhou, Hainan, Hubei, Hunan, Jiangsu, Jiangxi, Qinghai, Sichuan, Xizang, Yunnan, and Zhejiang, as well as in Taiwan.[5]

It is considered an exotic plant, and a weed, at the Meteor Downs South Project near Rolleston, Queensland, Australia.

My uncle was a nuc on the USS Alabama SSBN 731, for about 18 years. The stories he has told me and the things he still refuses to tell me, are fascinating. I remember as a kid, we were watching The Hunt for Red October. At one point, they mentioned launch depth being 150 ft. My uncle looked at me and said "I guess they declassified THAT information." We had a good laugh about it.
Then, I had watched Crimson Tide about half a dozen times, before it clicked in my head, that it was about my uncle's ship. So we talked about it and watched it one day and he pointed out all the little details that were correct or not. I have a few friends, who I met through World of Warcraft, who are submariners. I've always had a fascination with military equipment and listening to people talk about it.
So thank you again, for making this video. I really appreciate the in-depth look you give your viewers and the respect your show everyone with whom you meet and speak.

A couple of non science questions here. If Submariners operate mostly autonomously, are the commanding staff on board trained in geopolitics or routinely assessed mentally as so they are of sound mind and informed to make the <del>correct</del> best decisions so they won't escalate/start a conflict? For example, during the Cuban missile crisis there were Soviet subs that were in hiding near the blockade but 1 in particular the B-59, they were radio silent and not surfaced for days, their batteries ran low and their air-conditioning had stopped. Possibly due to the very difficult conditions on board (hot and hard to breath) at this time the captain had thought it was possible that war had started and wanted to launch a Nuclear Torpedo and was only talked down by the political officer and Flotilla Commodore (which was only dumb luck that he was on board this particular vessel). Do submariners (or even other front line COs) ever get rules of engagement like "Use your best judgement" or words to that affect so ranking officials can pass off any responsibility if they were to mess up?

As someone who served in the US Navy, onboard a fast attack submarine - the USS Santa Fe (SSN 763) - this bring back fond memories. Thanks for sharing your experience Destin. You really are part of a very small band of brothers and sisters who serve in the silent service. I can't wait to watch this series as you continue putting out videos. BTW - I was a Nuclear Electronics Technician (one of those guys who operated the nuclear reactor).

Fun fact: Submariners work rotational shift work on an 18 hour day - consisting of 6 hours on watch and 12 off. During the off time, we did a lot of different things - play cards, watch movies, study, conduct qualification checkouts or proficiency watches, clean, eat, do laundry, and somewhere in there - find a few hours to get some sleep. Every trip out to sea was exhausting.

I helped do an overhaul on a Collins Class submarine in Australia, and was absolutely amazed at the technology packed into these things, and just how well engineered and 'packed' together submarines are. Absolutely every item is weighed, sized and purpose built specifically for the task. But what amazed me the most were the people that devoted their lives to sailing these things. 3 months stuck in a tin can full of explosives with no contact with the outside world, working on rotating shifts hot bedding it, juniors sleeping next to torpedos, literally tripping over each other... Even things like showers are a luxury. It takes an incredible amount of mental stamina to do this job, and these people amaze me. Thanks Destin, i thoroughly enjoyed that.

That orange flower that attracts butterflies is Asclepias tuberosa, also called butterfly weed. It is a milkweed (the genus Asclepias) and is an important food source for Danaus plexippus, the monarch butterfly. The D. plexippus larvae only eat milkweed, plants of the genus Asclepias. Sadly, as the common name of the genus Asclepias is milkweed, it is treated as a pest, so D. plexippus, the monarch, is endangered. Asclepias tuberosa is quite easy to grow as an ornamental in a flower bed, too. It is easy to transplant, as it has tubers and will easily grow from the seeds (I imagine you have seen lots of the fluffy seeds come out of the pods in the summer or fall.)

The Latin name is "Asclepias tuberosa", but in NW Georgia, I grew up calling them -- wait for it -- "Butterfly bush". When I was a kid (many years ago) it was not uncommon to be drafted as a "Butterfly bush" toter, when my mother or grandmother would pull over to collect flowers for the Sunday dinner table. (The plant is a perennial, so cutting flowers doesn't seem to hurt it, since we collected flowers from the same spots for years.)

Officers earn their 'Dolphins' (Surface Warfare) by becoming qualified on all of the submarine's systems which takes longer, whereas Enlisted only are required to know the fundamentals of the systems. For those who didn't notice, or don't get it... It said (brackets added by me for grouping done graphically on the shirt): [E/c^2][√-1][PV/nR]

E/c^2 is an algebraic rearrangement of Einstein's simplified mass-energy equation E=mc^2. m = E/c^2, so that one's M.
The square root of -1 is i
PV/nR is referring to the ideal gas law, PV = nRT (Pressure * volume = the number of moles * the ideal gas constant * temperature), so rearranging that gives PV/nR = T.

M, I, T... MIT. Est. 1861. So clever!

I was in the Navy for nearly 24 years, retiring as a Chief Petty Officer.  I served aboard "Targets,"  the submariners' love/hate term for surface ships.  Not because I wanted to as I originally enlisted in the Polaris Missile Electronics Program.  That program involved training as an Electronics Technician, Polaris Missile School, Submarine School, and likely as not, Nuclear Power School.  I washed out in ET School due to a very poor knowledge of Algebra.  My Algebra, even though I passed the high school freshman edition, barely, could not understand how a 'letter' could be a number.  And too, I didn't catch the part about numbers changing signs on different sides of the equal sign, or the order of operation of the signs.  Later, in college work, I excelled in Algebra, Calculus, Geometry/Trigonometry, and Static Physics.  I will definitely be watching your series about our Navies undersea warriors.  If I had my college professors as instructors in the Navy, I would have retired as a Dolphin wearing Missile Tech.  A wonderful start of a grand topic

There's whole books worth of knowledge in every detail; take the diving procedure at 5:40, for example.

When you hear the callout "I intend to stationary dive...", that may sound similar to the classical "permission to dive?", but it's the result of a radical rethinking of ship operations that distributes authority to the crew. For a high-skill, high-trust team like a submarine crew, it's a third option that's better than asking for permission or for forgiveness.

The book Turn the Ship Around by L. David Marquet is a great read, with that story and lots of other surprising management insights.

One thing that was touched on and needs to really be emphasized, is that to earn your Dolphins, you need to have a complete working knowledge of every system, every compartment of the boat. Consider this, if there is an emergency onboard involving flooding, where compartments must be isolated, hatches closed. If you are the navigator onboard, and you happen to find yourself in engineering space, isolated, you must know what to do, how to operate the equipment, etc.. Also, take the enlisted men and women onboard. They are very intelligent obviously. Many of them hold college degrees, some of them advanced degrees. My Dad was a nuclear submariner for 26 years and he told me that one of his sonar men, an enlisted sailor, had a PHD in physics.
I never met a sub chop that was capable of anything, let alone giving the boat tour to a camera crew.

Something that may not be clear as to the job of the XO. Spent 6 years in the Navy, was on 2 ships...the last the USS New Jersey (BB62).
The XO's job is to know all of the things going on, on the ship. One of his primary jobs is to be the heavy. He is the one to maintain discipline on the ship...he's kept up to date on all issues and if the chain can't handle it, he does. He does everything he can to make sure the Captain doesn't have to handle a problem. He keeps the CO in the loop, but the XO has a lot of things he can do to take care of issues without making it serious.

When the CO HAS to step in, he generally has to use the big boot. If he's forced to take note of a problem, then it goes from a minor issue to "you are now officially screwed".

The XO's job is to make sure dad doesn't have to take off his belt. Because he will, because he HAS to. There can be no "stop or i'll say stop again...and maybe yell a bit". He's got to stomp on those problems hard, everybody knows this as an absolute fact...and act accordingly.

The part when Destin was with the enlisted guys and the captain and the captain said he liked hanging out with the chiefs it reminded me of a way we had meetings at a company I once worked for. In these meetings we would have many levels of management in the room. At the end of these meetings the highest ranking person would announce that we are at the "No B.S." point.

This meant that the remaining part of the meeting was for everyone to speak their mind. There was no rank, no positions, no retaliation for any commants. Anyone can say what they want but they have to listen to what anyone else says.

I wonder if the captain has been in with the enlisted men and said that it was a "No B.S." time and removed his rank insignia. It would probably take a while for the crew to get used to it but it would probably become a great tool for him and others.

The first few times we had our "No B.S." times it was akward for for us. Then the next couple of meetings became funny "no b.s."session. It wasn't until the 4th or 5th "no b.s." time that we really got into it and started sharing the details that we normally wouldn't share with upper management. But then this made it easier for us to bring up similar issues at any time.

We had grown as a group and were able to communicate issues we had that we were uncomfortable to bring up in the past. When I have told others what we used to do they thought that it would degenerate into a hate session or a venting session where were tell off others.

There was a little of that but then we started seeing the value in having a time where everyone was on the same level, there was no rank and no fear of retaliation for anything.

Thanks so much for this content, in particular. As a former MM2/ELT (2nd class petty officer, Nuclear Machinist's Mate and Engineering Laboratory Technician) who served aboard a Benjamin Franklin-class ballistic missile submarine, I especially appreciate the view you're providing to those unfamiliar with the workings of a U.S. Navy submarine.

One thing to note is just how much of the boat is the sole domain of officers and nuclear-trained enlisted personnel. Over a third of the Toledo is restricted, and that makes a huge difference for those who are nuclear-trained. It means we have the run of the boat, while non-nuclear enlisted are limited to spaces forward of the reactor compartment.

Beyond the training and experiences afforded me during my service, the single most influential thing that sticks with me four decades after leaving the USS Will Rogers (SSBN 659) for the last time is, in a word, excellence. Nuclear submarines are a marvel of modern engineering, operating in an environment every bit as unforgiving as outer space, crewed by some of the most intelligent, dedicated and all-around incredible people one would ever meet.

Back in the day on a "boomer", we deployed for 65 days submerged, operating on 18-hour days that consisted of 6 hours on watch, 6 hours studying and 6 hours sleeping. Most every "free" moment one had was spent studying, gaining proficiency and testing toward qualifications (earning one's dolphins). This took the better part of a minimum two tours.

I'm very much looking forward to the next in your Deep Dive series on nuclear submarines. What a privilege and an honor it was for your to be afforded the opportunity to spend 24 hours operating on a fast attack boat. I know those are experiences you'll cherish for a lifetime.

Be well and do good work.

I've been out of the Navy for 48 years now...and I STILL miss being on Submarines. Thanks for showing a glimpse into a very special world. Every submariner is a volunteer, and earning your dolphins is one of the most significant things that happens to a submariner..until you earn your dolphins you never feel like you're really part of the crew. Once you DO earn them you understand what that feeling means. Every person on your boat knows what to do, wherever they are on the boat, whether it's fully lit or total blackness, they know where every valve is and what it does, where every electrical switch is, where every air manifold is and what to do no matter what the circumstances are. I've been out of the submarine service for 48 years, and I STILL am in contact with a lot of my shipmates. It's an amazingly strong brotherhood..and now it's a sisterhood too. For your next submarine read I'd recommend Blind Man's Bluff, it will amaze you!

I first operated a Navy nuclear reactor when I was 19, during the second half of NPS (Nuclear Power School). Fortunately, the reactor was an on-shore nuclear prototype, so sinking was not an option. I had orders to a "boomer" (ballistic missile submarine) when life intervened and I had to switch from nuclear service to the "conventional" (non-nuclear) surface fleet.

The initial feeling of loss, to not use the training I had worked so hard to learn, was crushing. Fortunately, my arrival in the fleet turned out to be beyond awesome, as my nuclear training had taught me how to push myself harder than I had believed possible, so I started zooming up the ranks, gaining yet more schooling along the way, ultimately resulting in my being chosen to help "buy" a brand new destroyer from the shipyard on behalf of the Navy, then help put her into commission, making me a "plankowner" on that ship.

I was looking forward to making Chief in record time, but became disillusioned as I realized how much less time I would be spending with my beloved equipment and systems, and how much more leadership, administration, counselling, and all the other command, HR-like and "paperwork" functions I would take on. I decided to stay technical, and tried to stay in the Navy while also going to college. At the time, NESEP (the Navy Enlisted Science Education Program) had just been "mothballed", so I knew I'd have to leave active duty and use my GI Bill instead.

I became an engineer, and while I stayed in the US Navy Reserves from the day I left active duty until they forced me to finally retire, I've worked as a civilian ever since. My engineering career has been fantastic, and I've been able to mainly do R&D most of the time, closer to the scientists than the production engineers, though I've also delivered many products to market. But the key to it all was how the US Navy took a confused 18 year-old, skilled him up, then turned him loose on huge challenges.

I'm forever grateful and honored.

However, this video was a bit hard to watch, in the "I was so close" sense. I saw bits and pieces of systems that, to this day, many decades later, I still know extremely well. The cadence of orders issued, acknowledged, and passed on. The camaraderie and mutual respect at all levels, the overriding sense of team and even family. Yet each as very distinct individuals, no common mold there, other than to service and duty.

There's a back story on the Sean Connery photo hanging in the crews mess. Apparently, during the sixties...James Bond was on a flight from Los Angeles to London when an in flight emergency forced his private jet to be diverted to Toledo. Subsequently, he was laid over in the city for 14 days. His layover finally over, he was finally about to depart when a local reporter asked him how his stay was. Sporting a raised eyebrow, Connery responded, "First prize one week in Toledo....second prize....two weeks in Toledo."

When you hear that the submarine does not communicate back when on a mission, an work quite autonomously, you think that's awesome and/or quite disturbing. But then, realize that before radio communication; all naval vessels were also completely autonomous most of the time, and they probably couldn't even receive orders. And only some times, maybe they could send messages to command if close enough to shore that homing pigeons could be used.

This means wars probably raged on for days and weeks, or even months after a peace agreement had been signed, simply because the frontline had not yet been told the war was over.

Why so few women on Subs? It isnt that hard.
First, remember when that guy said "first thing out of a prospect's mouth is 'I dont want to be on a Submarine',"? That's true for women, too.
Second, Subs require, for men or women, top performance AND a specific mental and emotional type. That removes a LOT of applicants.
Third, integrated commands cause additional problems. And when you are underwater for six months (especially under ice!), you really want to avoid additional problems!
Fourth, retention. High power firms go to psychiatrists and psychologists all the time and ask "how can we retain more women? They power their way to top levels in the company, then they quit." Few enough men are willing to spend six months or more away from home. Fewer women are.

My guess is that you will never see the ratio of women-to-men on a submarine exceed 100-to-1, if that.
